title: ADDvocacy Website
summary: My work term with ADDvocacy was a valuable learning experience in efficiencies and making adjustments and improvements to an existing system. On the public-facing website, I helped them keep links up to date and formatted the Community Resources page. A lot of my work that semester, however, was on internal systems. Together with digital architect Thuy Vo, I redesigned the intake process, making use of Google Scripting connected to Forms, Sheets, and more. The new process saves the business dozens of hours every semester.

title: Aprimon Tracker
summary: The Aprimon Tracker's original form was a vanilla app for a single user, allowing that person to keep track of their collection in extensive detail. I really enjoyed working on it, and it's an impressive feat for the skills I was working with at the time. It uses a JSON dataset and a very simple PHP backend. The more impressive features are the sorting and filtering.

title: Countries Quiz
summary: Created a vanilla JavaScript app that fetches data from an API and displays it. Implemented a quiz interface. Designed and implemented basic styling.

title: Facet Cards
summary: The Facet Cards applet was one of the first things I did using JavaScript as a programming language, as opposed to as an extension of webpage styling. It's a simple randomized reading using a dataset inspired by one of my creative projects, and the first project I did after starting school that wasn't for any coursework.

title: Final Assignment XIV
summary: Created a vanilla JavaScript app that displays information fetched from an API and from a local JSON dataset. Designed and implemented complex SCSS styling.

title: Gallery
summary: The Sample Gallery is one of several similar galleries I've built, over the years. In this case, I wanted to make it look professional and functional while being as easy to maintain as possible for an artist with no background in programming.

title: Dragons Social
summary: Dragons Social is a fairly simple Laravel social media app, created in our coursework to learn more about Laravel and PHP at large. It also uses a lot of Bootstrap styling, cutting out the work of writing styles from scratch while still delivering a clean look.

title: Transit Tracker
summary: Created a JavaScript app that displays HRM buses in real time, fetching data from an API.

title: NSRAP Website
summary: Created a data-rich website with many pages. Designed and implemented CSS styling. Consulted with a Board to establish and meet requirements.

title: Squares Game
summary: The Squares Game was one of the school's first projects involving API data. It uses some complex logic to check whether the game has been completed successfully. It also introduced us to some core concepts, such as making sure the data is not dependent on the display. In a later semester, myself and my classmate Michele extended this project and used Google and Firebase Analytics to track our friends' use of the game.

title: Harbour Flight
summary: Harbour Flight was one of the larger projects I did as part of my NSCC coursework. According to the project guidelines, it needed to make fully interactive use of a medium-complexity dataset of our own making. Inspired by my mother's birdwatching and use of iNaturalist, I created an app that can be used to track bird sightings.

title: AquaLunae
summary: The AquaLunae website itself is a simple React applet. I wanted to use bold styling while also making the information easily browsable. In addition to the code of it, I also created the vector graphics.

title: Shelter Asset Tracker
summary: The Shelter Asset Tracker is one of the projects I'm most proud of. Together with Michele Moore, I was hired by Shelter Nova Scotia to solve a long-running problem in their organization: keeping track of the furniture and appliances in their buildings. I worked as both the project manager and front-end developer, with Michele as the back-end developer and database architect. We had many meetings with Shelter's staff to establish their exact needs and goals. The final product is an app that's as easy as possible for their house managers to use, while also being a powerful reporting tool for their finances and operations. They're excited to put it to work, and we can't wait to hear how it helps them.

title: PSSHRN Website
summary: In my final semester at NSCC, I was hired by Lisa Mader through Applied Research, on behalf of the Post-Secondary Student Homelessness Research Network. A long-running and vitally relevant research project, one of the stipulations for their grant funding was to have their findings publicly available. Of the work that they did, the Global Resources Scan and the Literature Review needed the most attention to be web-ready: I converted these vast spreadsheets into a series of easily searchable WordPress posts, all contained in a custom theme to their specifications. It was a valuable exercise in working with a non-technical team.

title: JavaScript String Utilities
summary: The JavaScript String Utilities package is a package born of frustration. After copying the same string-to-title function into half a dozen projects, I decided to bundle it and some other common needs. It's been a dependency in a lot of my other projects since.

title: Aprimon Tracker Reboot
summary: The new version of the Aprimon Tracker is a full-featured multi-user app built in React and Redux, with TypeScript. It also leverages Mongoose and a MongoDB backend, instead of storing data in JSON files. The inner workings of it have been completely overhauled to be more efficient and powerful, while still keeping the same look and feel as the original. The accessibility of this app is still in progress.
